word.entryExample: We keep on hearing about the environmental damage we cause.

word.entryDescription: to move, change or develop at the same speed as somebody/something
word.entryExample: Builders are not able to keep pace with demand for houses.

word.entryDescription: a container with a small open hole for pouring and a handle, used to boil water in
word.entryExample: Tanya puts the kettle on, so they can have a cup of tea.

word.entryDescription: a small thin piece of metal that you put into a small hole in order to lock or unlock a door
word.entryExample: Then I tell them their room number and give them their key.

word.entryDescription: to put information into a computer or other device by means of a keyboard or keypad
word.entryExample: First of all I have to switch my computer on and key in my password when it starts working.

word.entryDescription: a set of buttons with numbers on, to operate a telephone, a television, etc
word.entryExample: The invented system uses the ordinary keypad on the telephone to generate messages on a screen.

word.entryDescription: to hit something (e.g. a ball) with your foot
word.entryExample: I'm not very good at kicking a ball.

word.entryDescription: a type of oven that is used for baking clay to make it hard
word.entryExample: There are no kilns in the village, so he fires his pots in the open.

word.entryDescription: a word that is short for kilogram
word.entryExample: We need two kilos of potatoes.

word.entryDescription: a unit for measuring the weight of 1000 grams
word.entryExample: How many kilograms does this washing machine weigh?

word.entryDescription: a unit for measuring distance; 1000 metres
word.entryExample: This weekend my parents want to go to the mountains, 300 kilometres away!

word.entryDescription: a traditional garment for men and boys from the Scottish Highlands
word.entryExample: In this photo I’m wearing a kilt.

word.entryDescription: someone who is kind likes to give and be helpful to other people
word.entryExample: It was very kind of her to drive us all the way home.

word.entryDescription: a man who rules a country because he is royal
word.entryExample: The lion is often called the king of animals.

word.entryDescription: a small building or structure open on one or more sides, used as a newsstand or a place for selling goods or conducting transactions
word.entryExample: Don’t worry – if you forget or lose your boarding pass you can print it again – either online or at the check in kiosk at the airport.

word.entryDescription: a set of tools, parts, pieces of equipment, etc that is used for a particular purpose
word.entryExample: Look mum, they’ve United’s new football kit in the window.

word.entryDescription: a room where you cook food
word.entryExample: Mum is making dinner in the kitchen.

word.entryDescription: a toy made of paper or cloth which you fly in the air while you hold it on a long string
word.entryExample: Let's fly a kite on the beach.

word.entryDescription: a young cat
word.entryExample: My cat has five kittens.

word.entryDescription: the part of your body where your upper and lower leg join
word.entryExample: My knee sometimes hurts after a very long walk.

word.entryDescription: (plural 'knives') a tool used for cutting food
word.entryExample: I haven't got a knife. Can you bring me one, please?

word.entryDescription: to have information in your mind or to have experience of something
word.entryExample: Do you know Ann?

word.entryDescription: an Australian animal like a small grey bear that lives in trees
word.entryExample: Can I take pictures of the koala in the tree?

word.entryDescription: a room or building in which scientific activities are done
word.entryExample: It will be sent to the laboratory for tests.

word.entryDescription: a narrow object made of two long bars with several small steps between them, used for climbing up and down
word.entryExample: The firefighter climbed a ladder and rescued the little cat from a tree.

word.entryDescription: a large area of water away from the sea which has land all around it
word.entryExample: Finland is famous for its lakes.

word.entryDescription: a young sheep, meat which comes from a young sheep
word.entryExample: The lamb is very small.

word.entryDescription: a thing you use in a room to make it light
word.entryExample: This lamp reminds me of some fairy tale - it is so beautiful!

word.entryDescription: an area of ground, especially when used for particular purpose, e.g. farming or building
word.entryExample: They only buy soya produced on land already cleared of forest.

word.entryDescription: a big hole in the ground you put waste into
word.entryExample: Councils want more recycling and less waste in landfill sites.

word.entryDescription: the moment when a space vehicle touches down
word.entryExample: Steve acknowledges the huge impact the Apollo 11 moon landing had on him.

word.entryDescription: an area of land that has a particular quality or appearance, used especially when talking about its appearance
word.entryExample: Montane forests are an important element of East Africa's landscapes.

word.entryDescription: the sudden sliding of earth or rocks, etc, down the side of a mountain or cliff
word.entryExample: Landslides can happen when the ground is highly unstable.

word.entryDescription: the study of the skills and systems used by people in spoken and written communication
word.entryExample: Kate finds languages difficult.

word.entryDescription: a flat computer which you can carry with you
word.entryExample: I love my new laptop – I take it with me everywhere and I can do my homework on it.
The changing rooms are large, with lots of hot showers!

word.entryDescription: a device connected to a computer which prints out documents, pictures, etc using laser light
word.entryExample: A laser printer will give you better quality copies.

word.entryDescription: arriving or happening after the time agreed or expected
word.entryExample: Hurry up, I don't want to be late for school.

word.entryDescription: at a future time
word.entryExample: See you later!

word.entryDescription: to make sounds with your voice, because you think something is funny or you are happy
word.entryExample: We laughed at the funny film.

word.entryDescription: to introduce a new product or service for sale
word.entryExample: The company held a press conference to launch their new product.

word.entryDescription: clothes, sheets, towels, etc that need to be washed or just have been washed
word.entryExample: We've got to do the laundry.

word.entryDescription: impressive in quality or quantity, and usually involving a lot of money
word.entryExample: Richer people would have a more formal, lavish dinner.

word.entryDescription: an official rule set up by society, or the whole system of rules
word.entryExample: The seals are protected by special laws.

word.entryDescription: somebody whose job is to help people with legal matters
word.entryExample: He's interested in rules and the law and he can remember facts. I think he'll be a lawyer.

word.entryDescription: a distinct amount of something which covers something else or exists between two other distinct amounts of something
word.entryExample: As you go down further through the layers of rock you find older and older fossils.

word.entryDescription: not wanting to work or make effort
word.entryExample: Peter is very lazy. He never helps me with the housework.

word.entryDescription: (plural 'leaves') a flat green thing that grows on a plant or a tree
word.entryExample: The leaves fall off the trees in autumn.

word.entryDescription: a sheet of paper or a small book advertising something or giving information about something
word.entryExample: The leaflet says that the sports centre isn't open on Sunday.

word.entryDescription: to understand and remember a piece of information
word.entryExample: I learn English.
